entry.title: Übermittlung statistische Kennzahl in Personalkostenplanung und -simulation funktioniert nicht
entry.content:
Wir wollen dieses Jahr erstmalig die Personalkostenplanung in SAP durchführen. Die Tests für die Primärkosten sind positiv verlaufen. 

Ich versuche im System eine statistische Kennzahl (FTE) zu erzeugen bzw. zu übermitteln. Der Kostenbestandteil ist entsprechend im Customizing angelegt und auch mit der korrekten statistischen Kennzahl verbunden. Im Kostenplanungslauf kann ich die statistische Kennzahl nicht einsehen und eine Übergabe an Controlling erfolgt auch nicht. Was kann ich noch tun? Dieser Teil ist in der Anleitung sehr schlecht beschrieben. 

Ich würde mich sehr über Unterstützung und Hinweise freuen. Vielen Dank!

Ulrike Escherich

entry.title: SAPで実現するサブスクリプション管理#1―あらゆる業界で進む「所有から利用」への大転換
entry.content:
「所有」から「利用」へ――サブスクリプションの“第二の波”を乗りこなす 

2019年、「サブスク」が新語・流行語大賞にノミネートされ、一躍ブームとなりました。その後は「サブスク疲れ」という言葉も生まれ、一時的に熱が冷めたように見えたかもしれません。 

しかし今、世界では新たな「第二の波」が押し寄せています。その波は、ソフトウェア業界にとどまりません。例えば、高価な農業機械を販売するのではなく、利用時間や収穫量に応じて課金するモデルや、航空機エンジンを販売せず、飛行時間に応じて利用料を徴収するモデルが広がっています。 

つまり、あらゆる業界で、製品そのものではなく、その利用・稼働時間・成果といった「価値」を提供するモデルへの移行が進んでいるのです。 
実際、2024年には4,923億ドル（約74兆円）規模に達し、2033年には1兆512億ドル（約157兆円）まで拡大すると予測されています。この成長は、年平均成長率（CAGR）13.3％という驚異的なスピードで進む見通しです。 

一方、日本市場では依然として「モノを売る」モデルから脱却できていない企業も多く見られます。しかし、消費者の価値観は確実に「所有」から「利用」へシフトしており、この変化に対応できるかどうかが、今後の成長を左右します。 

本シリーズでは、サブスクリプションビジネスを成功させるためのヒントを、SAPのソリューションとともに解説します。第1回の今回は、最新の市場動向と企業が直面する課題を整理します。 

なぜ今、サブスクなのか？ 

サブスクリプションへの移行は、顧客の期待と市場の変化という2つの大きな潮流によって加速しています。 

 1.顧客ニーズの変化 

かつては「所有すること」が価値でしたが、今の顧客は**“必要な時に、必要な分だけ”**の利用を求めています。例えば、音楽をCDで買うのではなく月額料金で聴き放題にしたり、車を購入するのではなく必要なときだけ乗るサービスを利用したりするように、求められる価値は以下の4つに集約されます。 

  • 容易なアクセス：即座に契約・利用できること。 
  • 柔軟な選択肢：期間や支払方法を自由に選べること。 
  • パーソナライズされた価値：個別最適化された商品やサービスを受けられること。 
  • 価値に基づく支払い：利用効果に応じた対価を支払うこと。 

2.市場トレンドの後押し 

顧客ニーズの変化を支えているのが、市場環境の変化です。 

  • 安定した収益確保：景気変動や災害などのリスクが発生しても、継続的な収益基盤を持つことで事業の安定化を図れる。 
  • AI・データ活用の加速：顧客データをAIで分析し、利用状況に応じた最適なプラン提案やアップセルを自動化できる。 
  • 企業価値の向上：継続収益を持つ企業は市場から高く評価され、投資家からの注目度も上昇する傾向にある。 

変化に対応できるかが成長の分かれ目 

今の潮流は、単なる料金体系の見直しではなく、ビジネスモデルそのものの転換です。従来の「製品販売」や「時間・工数売り」から、次のような多層的で柔軟なモデルへと進化しています。 

  • Everything-as-a-Service：あらゆる製品やサービスを利用ベースで提供。 
  • 成果ベース課金：利用時間や成果物など、実際の価値に応じて課金。 
  • パーソナライズされたバンドル：顧客ごとに異なる商品・サービスを組み合わせて提供。 
  • パートナー製品との組み合わせ：他社製品や外部サービスを統合し、一体型の価値を提供。 

これらのモデルは、顧客への提供価値を最大化すると同時に、企業にとっても収益機会を拡大します。つまり、この変化にいち早く対応できる企業こそが、新たな市場をリードし、持続的な成長を実現できるのです。 

サブスク拡大の前に立ちはだかる課題 

サブスクリプションビジネスは、大きな成長機会をもたらす一方で、多くの企業が特有の課題に直面しています。特に、この分野で既存のITシステムを使い続けている企業にとって、ビジネスモデルの変革は容易ではありません。 
 

その主な要因として、以下の点が挙げられます。 

  • 複雑な料金モデルの管理: 多様な料金体系やキャンペーンを扱うサブスクビジネスでは、従来のITシステムでは処理しきれず、手作業に頼ることが増えてしまいます。 
  • 契約中の対応の煩雑さ: 契約内容の変更や解約といった「モノ売り」にはなかったプロセスが頻繁に発生します。既存のシステムではこれらの変更に柔軟に対応できず、マニュアル作業が増加する原因となります。 
  • 正確かつ迅速な請求処理の必要性: 月次や利用ベースなど、請求の頻度や件数が大幅に増えるため、スピーディーかつ正確な処理体制が不可欠です。 
  • システム連携の難しさ: 顧客管理（CRM）、会計、データ分析など、複数のシステムをリアルタイムで統合・連携させるための複雑な構築が求められます。 

これらのIT側の課題を解決しないままでは、サブスクリプションビジネスはスケールせず、せっかくのビジネスモデルの転換が形骸化してしまうリスクに直面します。 

まとめ 

サブスクリプションは、もはや選択肢の一つではなく、成長戦略の中核となるビジネスモデルです。しかし、その成功の鍵は、これらの複雑な課題をどう解決するかにかかっています。 

次回は、これらの課題を解決するQuote-to-Cashソリューション（SAP Subscription Billingなど）の機能やアーキテクチャについて詳しくご紹介します。サブスクビジネスの導入や拡大を検討中の方は、ぜひ次回もお読みください。

entry.title: Re: RFUI: Default Presentation Device field – Enter key d...
entry.content:
Hello @FlorisBoon 

The behaviour you’re experiencing with the Enter key in the RFUI on mobile devices, where Android Velocity scanners do not trigger validation or submission, unlike on desktop browsers, is a known discrepancy in how keyboard events are handled across platforms.

Key points:

  • On desktop browsers, pressing Enter triggers validation and auto-filling of the Default Presentation Device based on customisation.
  • On mobile devices with Velocity Zebra scanners running Android and Chrome, pressing the Enter key does not trigger the expected events, requiring users to manually tap the OK button.
  • This inconsistency breaks the expected flow and reduces user efficiency in warehouse processes.
  • As a workaround, remapping the Enter key to Tab or OK key events using the Ivanti Velocity Console does trigger the validation/submit and fills the Default Presentation Device correctly.

Is this a known limitation?

This behaviour arises from differences in how web browsers on desktops versus Android Velocity browsers interpret keyboard events, especially the Enter key. In the Velocity environment, the Enter key (keycode 66) isn’t always mapped to trigger form submissions or validations.

Scope of responsibility:

  •  The issue likely falls partly under the scanner configuration or customisation scope (handled by scanner/image vendors using tools like Ivanti Velocity Console) since remapping keys can resolve it.
  • Functional SAP consultants should be aware of this limitation and collaborate with the technical team for a smooth user experience, but the core fix often lies in device or browser key event handling.

Suggested SAP action/request:

  •  Confirming this as a limitation through SAP Notes or product documentation would be useful.
  • A product correction or enhancement to unify Enter key behaviour across desktop and Velocity might be requested via SAP Customer Influence or support channels

 SAP References and further reading:

  • SAP Screen Personas for Mobile RF Devices in EWM in S/4HANA, how RFUI screens are personalized and managed on mobile devices

SAP EWM RFUI default device assignment and key handling (some insights in SAP community blogs and guides)

  • https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-blog-posts-by-members/sap-ewm-rf-developments/ba-p/13521929
  • https://docs.theconfigteam.com/prebilt-ewm/configuration-guide/overview
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-q-a/rfui-default-presentation-device-field-enter-key-does-not-trigger-submit-on/qaq-p/14182582
  • https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_EXTENDED_WAREHOUSE_MANAGEMENT/3d97bec9bf1649099384bb8167df3cf2/90c9cb53ad377114e10000000a174cb4.html

Ivanti Velocity Console documentation for key remapping on Zebra scanners

  • https://forums.ivanti.com/Community/s/question/0D54O00006sTdemSAC/remap-some-keys-with-velocity-console?language=fr
  • https://download.wavelink.com/files/velocity-ug-11-040620142.pdf
  • https://help.ivanti.com/wl/help/en_us/velsim/1.2/admin/keyboardcodes.htm

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: SAP Ariba Procure to Order 2508 Release Key Innovations
entry.content:
Hello, SAP Ariba Community! We're thrilled to reveal some fantastic new innovations in our upcoming release, 2508, including the much-anticipated initial release of Joule—our digital AI copilot in Guided Buying. Additionally, we have more exciting updates to share regarding WalkMe enhancements, improvements to the Mobile experience, and advancements in virtual card capabilities. Stay tuned for these highlights!

AI Copilot Joule in Guided Buying (GUIDEB-1163)

We're excited to introduce Joule, SAP's generative AI copilot, now available in Guided Buying. Joule features a conversational interface designed to help users complete tasks efficiently. It leverages generative and other AI technologies to understand natural language requests, identify user intent, perform actions, and provide valuable insights.

With Joule, you can easily access information such as:

  • Requisition approval status
  • Requisition details
  • Recent purchases

You can find the Joule panel by clicking on the icon at the top of your screen. This release is just the beginning of our journey to harness AI across buying processes, driving significant efficiency gains and more for our entire user base.

 Please note that AI copilot Joule in Guided Buying will be in Early Access until September 19th, 2025 at which time it will be made generally available to customers

For more detailed information please see this blog: Joule in SAP Ariba Applications

Enhancements to WalkMe in Guided Buying (GUIDEB-1266)

We were excited to announce the first iteration of WalkMe in Guided Buying in the last release (2505), now to build on this momentum with an important user experience enhancement.

The WalkMe Digital Adoption Platform is now enabled for all Guided Buying customers and the WalkMe panel can now display content from SAP Companion also through some subtle UI changes.

If both WalkMe and SAP Companion are enabled, the walk me panel now displays a separate tab for each respectively:

 

Previously, WalkMe was disabled by default, and SAP Companion content displayed in a different panel.

This innovation offers more flexibility, allowing you to use the right resources and support at the right time in the most suitable way. It will help guide you seamlessly through your desired procurement processes and drive better outcomes.

 

Asset Management in Guided Buying (GUIDEB-915)

We're excited to introduce a new feature that brings enhanced asset management capabilities to Guided Buying. Here's what you need to know:

 Seamless Asset Management Integration

This feature enables you to manage assets directly in Guided Buying using the asset management functionality from your SAP ERP system. With this integration, you can now manage your organization's assets throughout their lifecycle, all within the familiar Guided Buying interface.

Streamlined Asset Workflow

When an asset manager is added to a purchase requisition, the request is automatically sent to the Asset Workbench for further classification. From there, you can easily assign asset-specific lines, asset groups, and monitor the status of your assets.

Easy Access to Asset Management

To make your asset management tasks even more convenient, we've added a dedicated Asset Workbench section right on the Guided Buying home page:

To submit purchase requisitions with assets and to manage assets in the Asset Workbench the user must belong to the Asset Manager Group.

Mass Editing of Accounting Information in SAP Ariba Procurement Mobile App (BMAA-472)

Users of the SAP Ariba Procurement Mobile App can now edit accounting information at the header level of a requisition through a new section called ‘Charge to’. This eliminates the need to edit accounting information for each line item—a process that could be particularly time-consuming for requisitions with multiple line items.

We understand that efficiency is key when you're buying on the go. This small but impactful change aims to streamline your overall mobile buying experience and save you valuable time.

Prepackaged Reports for Virtual Card Orders (PROC-1011)

We have created a new entry to the pre-packaged reports in to help analyse V-Card transactions and corresponding data.

The Virtual Card Reports folder contains the prepackaged reports for:

  • Virtual Card orders
  • Virtual Card Charges Load Report
  • Virtual Card Charge Reconciliation Report
  • Virtual Card Charge Exception Report

We believe these new reports will significantly enhance your ability to analyze and manage virtual card usage, leading to more informed decision-making and improved financial controls.

Stay tuned for more updates and innovations designed to empower your procurement processes!

  • Register for the Early Release Series for 2508 release
  • Resources:
    • SAP Ariba Connect - Release Readiness (Customers except CIM)
    • Readiness Community page (For CIM customers)
    • Feature related materials
    • SAP Community for Intelligent Spend Management page
    • SAP Help Portal pages - Procurement  
    • What’s New

entry.title: Re: Budget is returned to available during the GR posting...
entry.content:
Hi,

What you are observing is consistent with how Funds Management (FM) and Asset Accounting (AA) interact during GR postings with account assignment A (Asset). A few key points to keep in mind:

🔍 Why the budget is being released at GR

  • With acct assignment A, the system considers the PO commitment against the WBS, but at GR (101), it treats the posting as an asset acquisition in progress.

  • Because the WBS is not yet carried into the AA line at GR, no CO document is generated, so FM sees the PO commitment released but does not see an “actual.”

  • That’s why your budget becomes available again after GR — the commitment is gone, but no consumption is posted yet.

At reversal (102), the system derives the WBS from the PO and updates the CO document, hence you see the budget consumption with a negative.

⚙️ Things to check in configuration

  1. Integration of Investment Management / Asset under Construction

    • If you want the budget to remain tied to the WBS until the asset is capitalized, you generally need to use Investment Measure (AuC with settlement to asset) rather than a direct Asset acquisition on the WBS.

    • Direct acquisition to the final asset with acct assignment “A” will always release the commitment at GR because CO posting is only triggered at Invoice (MIRO) or Settlement.

  2. ACSET maintenance

    • Ensure WBS is marked as relevant in ACSET for the account assignment object (Asset).

    • If missing, the WBS will not be derived at GR, only at reversal.

  3. G/L and Cost Element setup

    • Even though you set the G/L to “Record Account Assignment” for asset acquisitions, the system only passes account assignment at the point of capitalization (not GR).

    • Check whether your acquisition G/L accounts are of category 90 vs. 01 (primary) and how that aligns with your CO posting expectations.

  4. Funds Management settings

    • In FM, commitment/actual update logic for Acct Assignment A differs from “K” (Cost Center) or “P” (WBS). If you need budget consumption at GR, you may need to adjust your FM update profile to recognize the posting category.

✅ Typical Approaches to Fix

  • Best practice: For project-related asset acquisitions, use AuC assets with settlement from WBS. That way, the WBS remains the budget object until capitalization, and budget consumption is consistent.

  • If you must stick with Acct Assignment A, then you may need a BAdI enhancement (e.g., FMACCCUST or AC_DOCUMENT) to derive and carry the WBS at GR so that the budget is consumed properly.

📌 Summary

What you’re seeing is “standard” behavior when posting GR to a fixed asset (Acct Assignment A). The system releases the commitment but does not consume budget until invoice posting or settlement. If your business requires budget consumption already at GR, the usual path is:

  • Change process to AuC acquisition with settlement, or

  • Implement an enhancement to force WBS derivation at GR.

👉 Quick question back: Is your process direct capitalization to the final asset from PO, or are you working with AuC assets and settlement from WBS? That detail will determine the cleanest fix.

"GenAI was used to help generate this content."

entry.title: Time accruals start date
entry.content:
Hi all,

 

I have an issue with an accrual rule.

The validity period starts September 1st and ends 31st of August next year.

So because of this the hire rule is not working correctly - If I hire an employee before 1st of September this year / example 2/02/2025/ I will get 2 accounts with the same date 2025, instead of one account starting 2.02.2025 - with name Holiday 2024 and the next one starting 1st of September 2025 - with name Holiday 2025. 

 

Ho I can make the configuration in order to work correctly and always to make the accounts to start 1st of September , meaning to match the account validity. Because the account creation is automatically set to be 4 months before validity period seems the Flexible start date in not an option. 

 

Please help me urgently as the implementation should go live in 2 weeks. 

 

Thanks

entry.title: Demo Jam @ SAP TechEd On Tour Bangalore | Nov 25–26, 2025 | BIEC
entry.content:
Bring Your Ideas to Life 

The wait is over – Demo Jam is back at SAP TechEd On Tour, happening on November 25–26 in Bangalore! This is your chance to wow customers and partners in the audience, showcase your most innovative SAP-powered solution, and prove your skills in a high-energy live showdown. 

What’s SAP Demo Jam? 

Think of it as the ultimate live demo battle - no slides, no filler. Just six minutes of pure creativity and innovation, live on stage. The winner? Chosen by the audience using our applause-o-meter. 
(Need ideas? Check out the 2023 SAP DemoJam Highlights.) 

Rules 

  • Time Limit: Exactly 6 minutes - go over and the buzzer cuts you off.
  • Live Demo Only: No PPTs, no screenshots, no videos, no AI-generated entertainment -only real, working solutions.
  • Tech Focus: Must show how you used SAP BTP (incl. SAP Build, APAB, SAP Integration Suite, HANA Cloud), SAP Business Data Cloud, and/or SAP Business AI to solve a real business problem.
  • Team Size: 2 presenters on stage.

How to Submit Your Proposal 

Email TechEdonTourBangalore2025@sap.com

Subject : SAP Demo Jam - SAP TechEd On Tour Bangalore 2025 

Details : 

  • Name of your demo 
  • Detailed description of your demo 
  • Business value you’re demonstrating (max 500 words) 
  • Technology used 
  • Presenter #1: Name, Email, Company, Job profile 
  • Presenter #2: Name, Email, Company, Job profile 
  • (Optional) Link to a short demo video 

Deadline: September 15, 2025 

What Happens Next? 

  • Selection of Finalists: Six teams will be chosen by an SAP expert panel and announced on September 25, 2025. 
  • Complimentary Tickets: Finalist presenters get complimentary SAP TechEd On Tour Bangalore tickets (travel & expenses not included). 
  • Live Demo: On November 26, finalists take the stage-two presenters per team-to battle it outlive.

Bring your ideas. Bring your energy. Bring your innovation. 

Let’s Jam, Bangalore!

entry.title: Re: How to remove a Billing Plan line item from Sales Order?
entry.content:
Deleting the date description and billing type alone doesn’t remove the line item.

In standard, if you clear all fields (Billing Type, Date Description, Billing Date, Amount) and set a Billing Block, the line becomes inactive. It won’t be billed, and standard billing programs will skip it. However, the line still exists in the billing plan; it’s just neutralized.

Do clear all the fields as below

Also, since your custom report still picks up this line, enhance the logic to exclude lines where:

  • Billing Type is blank
  • Billing Date is initial
  • Billing Block is active
  • Amount is zero

This way, the line remains in the document for audit purposes but is excluded from operational use.

entry.title: Re: Docker ABAP Cloud Developer Trial 2023 Eclipse Projec...
entry.content:
As part of our SAP Community, many of us experiment with ABAP in the cloud, and Docker is a great way to set up a local trial for learning and sharing. Here’s a simple guide that fellow writers, app developers, and software freelancers can follow to create an ABAP Cloud project in Eclipse using the 2023 trial setup.

Step 1: Prepare Docker Environment

Install Docker Desktop (Linux, Windows, or macOS).

Pull the official ABAP Cloud Developer Trial 2023 image:

https://devtechnosys.com/


docker pull saplabs/abap-cloud-trial:2023
Run the container:


docker run -it -p 8000:8000 saplabs/abap-cloud-trial:2023
This will start your trial system locally.

Step 2: Install Eclipse with ABAP Development Tools (ADT)

Download Eclipse IDE (2023-XX version recommended).

In Eclipse, go to Help > Install New Software, add the update site for ADT:


 tools.hana.ondemand
Select ABAP Development Tools, then finish the installation.

Step 3: Create ABAP Cloud Project

Open Eclipse > File > New > ABAP Cloud Project.

Enter your local Docker ABAP trial connection details (host: localhost, port 8000).

Log in with the default developer credentials provided in the Docker container.

Your ABAP Cloud Project is ready for development and testing.

Step 4: Start Exploring
You can now create ABAP classes, CDS views, and RAP applications directly inside Eclipse. This environment is perfect for freelance practice, prototyping, and sharing knowledge within the SAP Community.

entry.title: Manage Purchase Order App – Header Level Condition Type Not Available for Landed Cost Elements
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

We are working on SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud 2023 and using the Fiori native app “Manage Purchase Orders”.

Issue observed:

  • In the app, we are not able to see or select header-level condition types.
  • Specifically, we require these condition types to capture landed cost elements (e.g., freight, insurance, customs duties).
  • In the classic GUI transactions (ME21N/ME22N), header conditions are available. However, in the Fiori app they do not appear.

Questions:

  1. Is this functionality supported in the Manage Purchase Orders app?
  2. If not available, is there any roadmap item or SAP Note that enables header-level conditions in this Fiori app?
  3. What is the recommended best practice for handling landed cost conditions if we want to work fully in Fiori without reverting to “Advanced” (GUI-based) apps?

Any guidance or references would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks,
Jeeva

entry.title: Re: Manage Purchase Order App – Header Level Condition Ty...
entry.content:
Header conditions are available in classic GUI transactions (ME21N/ME22N) and the “Create Purchase Order – Advanced” Fiori app, but not in the standard “Manage Purchase Orders”.

SAP Note 2498496 confirms that header-level features (including header text and conditions) are not supported in the “Manage Purchase Orders” app. Not sure on the official roadmap to enable header-level conditions, available for this which you can check in the SAP Roadmap Explorer and influence via Customer Influence Portal. SAP recommends using the Advanced apps for scenarios requiring header-level pricing.

Below are some of the recommended approaches

  • Define landed cost condition types (e.g., freight, insurance) at the item level. These can be apportioned across items and reflected in the header totals. This is the most compatible approach with the current Fiori app capabilities.
  • Use “Create Purchase Order – Advanced” App. This app supports header-level conditions and is Fiori-based but retains GUI-like functionality. Ideal for users who need full pricing flexibility but want to avoid SAP GUI.

entry.title: Random Numbers and Probability Distributions in the ABAP Environments for 2508
entry.content:
Random Numbers and Probability Distributions in the ABAP Environments for 2508

1 Introduction

Can ABAP generate random numbers? If you're nodding yes, you're in the right place.

Most ABAP developers would instinctively say "yes"—after all, who hasn't used CL_ABAP_RANDOM for generating test data? But if you've ever looked under the hood, you'll know that not all random numbers are created equal. Every random number generator is tied to a probability distribution.

Here's the twist: Until now, ABAP only spoke the language of uniform randomness—a far cry from the rich, varied distributions that reflect real-world and business data.

The great news? With the latest ABAP releases, the answer has changed. ABAP now speaks the whole language of probability, supporting versatile random number generation for your advanced business needs!

It also has all the functionality to compute with probabilities. Just enough to make ABAP your probability workbench for every day's use.

Note: currently planned to be available on-premise and in the private cloud with the upcoming major SAP S/4HANA release in 2025. Please note that this plan is subject to change by SAP without prior notice.

2 Example: Customer Payment Date

Suppose you want to generate realistic data for customer payment dates. Do you imagine that customers pay at random, with every date being equally likely?

Of course not!

In reality, most customers settle their bills close to the due date, with a few paying a bit early or late, and only a handful paying extremely early or well past the deadline.

These patterns can be captured with various probability distributions, such as normal, beta, or exponential distributions. If you treat payment dates as discrete events, distributions like Poisson or multinomial may also fit.

For simplicity, we'll focus on the most common and versatile: the normal distribution. The normal distribution's importance comes from a deep and beautiful mathematical result, the central limit theorem. Simply put, it says:

If you average many independent random processes—even if each one follows a different pattern—their average or sum will tend to form the familiar bell-shaped curve known as the normal distribution.

In short, the normal distribution is the most important probability distribution. 

Probability density of the normal distribution

The curve means that the normal distribution generates values around its mean value (here: zero) more often and values farther away less frequently. This can easily be adjusted to give a more realistic simulation of customer payment dates.

The ABAP code is surprisingly easy compared to other programming languages. It uses the new system class CL_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION and its method NEXT_RANDOM_NUMBER( ). This class needs an underlying uniform random number generator given by an interface IF_ABAP_RANDOM. The old class CL_ABAP_RANDOM happens to implement IF_ABAP_RANDOM.

class payment_date_generator definition.
  public section.
    methods constructor importing rng type ref to if_abap_random. " new as well
    methods generate_payment_date importing due_date type d
                                  returning value(payment_date) type d.

  private section.
    data m_rng type ref to if_abap_random.
    data m_system_date type d.
    data m_distribution type ref to if_abap_prob_distribution.
endclass.

class payment_date_generator implementation.
  method constructor.
    m_rng = rng.
    m_system_date = cl_abap_context_info=>get_system_date( ).
    m_distribution = cl_abap_prob_distribution=>get_normal_distribution(
      mean = 0
      standard_deviation = 15 ). " 68% are within ±15 days around due date
  endmethod.

  method generate_payment_date.
    while payment_date < m_system_date.
      payment_date = due_date + 
         conv i( m_distribution->next_random_number( rng = m_rng ) ).
    endwhile.
  endmethod.
endclass.

Using the new interface IF_ABAP_RANDOM, you can also plug in your own uniform random number generator. No need to take the ABAP one (just in case you need a cryptographically secure, normally distributed number). Using ABAP's CL_ABAP_RANDOM is faster, as special optimizations apply here.

Running the example on 2025/08/06 with due date 2025/08/20 and 1000 numbers gives the following histogram, for example:

Note: Although the normal distribution is symmetric around the mean value, we arrived at a non-symmetric distribution by "cutting off" the dates before the current date. This is called rejection sampling, and it gives a totally new probability distribution, unique to this business problem.

Implementation: There are two ABAP classes:

ClassDescriptionHint
CL_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTIONCalculate with F (= FLOAT) probabilitiesFaster, more distributions
CL_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION_DF34Calculate with DECFLOAT34 probabilitiesMuch slower, fewer distributions

By default, the classes CL_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION and CL_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION_DF34 generate F or DECFLOAT34 numbers, but they can easily be cast to P, I, or other datatypes in different scenarios.

Both classes can generate I (= INT4) or INT8 random numbers for discrete distributions by default using separate methods.

3 Supported probability distributions

In the ABAP environments 2508, the following distributions are supported:

DistributionTypeCL_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION
(FLOAT Probabilities)		CL_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION_DF34
(DECFLOAT34 Probabilities)		Business Example
Normal distributionContinuousYesYesCustomer satisfaction scores, Employee performance, and financial returns follow a normal distribution.
Lognormal distributionContinuousYesYesRevenue or units sold across a product catalog often follow a lognormal distribution. 
Exponential distributionContinuousYesYesThe duration of customer service calls can be modeled using an exponential distribution.
Gamma distributionContinuousYesYesA gamma distribution can model the time it takes to complete a project and the distribution of customer lifetime values (CLV) in CRM.
Chi-Squared distributionContinuousYesYesTest whether the customer prefers a new product feature over an existing one using the famous chi-squared test, which utilizes the chi-squared distribution.

Uniform-int/int8 distribution

Discrete

YesYes

Companies often conduct customer surveys in market research to gather feedback and insights. To ensure that the survey results represent the entire customer base, a uniform integer distribution can be used for random sampling.

Poisson distributionDiscreteYesNoUnderstanding customer traffic is crucial for staffing and operational decisions in retail management. The Poisson distribution can model the number of customers arriving at a store within a specific time interval.
Binomial distributionDiscreteYesNo

In manufacturing, the binomial distribution can be used to model the number of defective items (failures) in a sample of produced items.

Student's t-distributionContinuousYesNoUsing the famous t-test and the t-distribution, one can test whether a new marketing campaign significantly affected sales.
Hypergeometric distributionDiscreteYesNoIn inventory management, the hypergeometric distribution can be used to model the selection of items for inspection or audit from a finite inventory.
Geometric distributionDiscreteYesNoModel the number of customer interactions needed until the first sales occur.

Note:  More probability distributions might evolve in future ABAP releases (not an official statement, no guarantee, no promise or roadmap item). Please note that this plan is subject to change by SAP without prior notice.

4 Calculating with probabilities

These new classes aren't just about rolling random numbers—they unlock many possibilities! Now you can compute probabilities, dive into advanced statistical analyses, and so much more.

The magic happens through the IF_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION interface, which lets you calculate cumulative distribution functions (CDFs), quantiles, and a range of other powerful statistical operations. Plus, with dedicated sub-interfaces for discrete distributions, you get even more specialized tools right at your fingertips.

Here we only talk about two very important methods:

MethodDescription
CDF (Cumulative Distribution Function)Calculates the probability that the distribution assumes values <= x. In mathematical terms: P(X <= x).
QuantileInverse of the CDF. The quantile function gives the smallest value x  such that the cumulative probability (CDF) is at least p.

Business Problem for the CDF: What proportion of the bills are paid within 20 days of the due date?
Solution in ABAP: 

 

  final(dist) =
    cl_abap_prob_distribution=>get_normal_distribution( mean = 0 standard_deviation = 15 ).
  final(proportion) = dist->cdf( 20 ).
  cl_demo_output=>display( proportion ).

 

Business Problem for the Quantile: You want to know when 95% of customers have paid their bills.
Solution in ABAP:

  data quantile type d.
  final(dist) =
    cl_abap_prob_distribution=>get_normal_distribution( mean = 0 standard_deviation = 15 ).
  final(quantile_int) = conv i( ceil( dist->quantile( '0.95' ) ) ).
  quantile = due_date + quantile_int.  
  cl_demo_output=>display( quantile ).

This prints 2025/09/14 in my example from above, i.e., in mid-September, 95% of the customers paid their bill (simplified calculation for demo purposes, which does not account for the rejection sampling method applied above. Special applause to anyone posting the solution for the truncated normal distribution in the comments below.)

Note that many valid statistical methods can be used to find the correct probability distribution for your business problem. These can also be implemented now in ABAP.  

5 More Trivia

With the new classes, you can also do funny stuff, which is not quite new, but was difficult or slow before.

5.1 Generate many random numbers at once

Usually, you do not want to generate only one random number. You want to generate many random numbers. In the past, every generated random number was a single method call.

Example:

  types i_tab type standard table of i with empty key.
  final(rng) = cl_abap_random=>create( ).
  final(tab) = reduce i_tab( init _tab = value #( ) 
                             for i = 1 then i + 1 until i > 1000
                             next _tab = value #( base _tab ( rng->int( ) ) ) ).

This is slow, as we have 1000 method calls and a FOR-LOOP.

Now, this can be sped up many times by doing the loop inside the ABAP kernel.

  final(rng) = cl_abap_random=>create( ).
  final(distrib) = cl_abap_prob_distribution=>get_uniform_int_distribution( range = value #( ) ). " empty range => all numbers
  final(tab) = distrib->next_random_numbers( count = 1000 rng = rng ).

  cl_demo_output=>display( tab ).

5.2 Analyzing range tables and generating random numbers in non-consecutive intervals

Another nice example is generating uniformly distributed integer random numbers in arbitrary subsets of the integers (i.e., not in a single contiguous interval). The constructor for the uniform integer distribution accepts a range table.

  data distrib type ref to if_abap_prob_distribution_int.
  final(rng) = cl_abap_random=>create( ).
  distrib = cl_abap_prob_distribution=>get_uniform_int_distribution(
    range = value #( ( sign = 'I' option = 'BT' low = 1 high = 10 )
                     ( sign = 'E' option = 'EQ' low = 5 ) ) ).
  cl_demo_output=>write( distrib->support_size( ) ).  " prints 9, i.e. we have 9 elements which are covered by the rangetab
  cl_demo_output=>write( distrib->median( ) ). " prints 6, which is the median of the set [1,2,3,4,6,7,8,9,10] in our definition  
  final(random_numbers) = distrib->next_random_numbers( count = 1000 rng = rng ). " generate random numbers from 1 to 10 excluding 5
  cl_demo_output=>display( random_numbers ).

Conclusion: You can easily generate random numbers that satisfy any condition specified by a range table. Keep in mind that the range table is treated as a set—so overlapping conditions like X < 6 and X < 7 simply combine to X < 7. Values that fall into both ranges (such as 5) are not given extra weight or counted multiple times.

Also, integers are "cut off" at the minimum/maximum INT4 or INT8 value, so you can't compute uniform discrete probabilities of an infinite set. Mathematics is safe here.

6 Overflows

When generating random numbers, a probability distribution can overflow. The normal distribution, for example, spans the whole real line. As FLOAT's value range is finite, this can lead to unexpected results for very large mean or standard deviation, or, if you are just "unlucky", also for small ones. 

We decided that random number generation should never overflow. We achieve this by two means:

    1.  Restricting the parameters for the distribution in the constructor to "sensible" values reflecting real-world scenarios.
    2.  If you are unlucky anyhow, use rejection sampling until we are in the float range. 

This is an important compromise and something that is not done in most random number generator libraries. It also means that the distribution may not exactly be (normally-, gamma-, ...) distributed at the borders of the float or decfloat range. This has no influence on any real-world scenario or calculation, however. 

On the contrary, you can be content that no overflow occurs, ever. This is an important feature of a random number generator. 

7 Conclusion

This article showcased the new ABAP capabilities for generating random numbers from various probability distributions—and performing probability calculations—using the powerful system classes CL_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION and CL_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION_DF34.

8 The interface IF_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION

For reference, here is the complete interface IF_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION with the implemented methods:

"! <p>Interface representing a probability distribution with probabilities of type F (=FLOAT). Used by class
"!  {@link CL_ABAP_PROB_DISTRIBUTION }, which represents a probability distribution over the real line.</p>
interface if_abap_prob_distribution
  public .

  "! Table type to hold a collection of random numbers.
  types random_numbers type standard table of f with empty key.

  "! Returns the support of the probability distribution
  "! @parameter kind | The kind of support the distribution provides.
  methods support_kind
    returning value(kind) type if_abap_prob_types=>support_kind.

  "! Returns the kind of probability distribution
  "! @parameter kind | The kind of the distribution.
  methods distribution_kind
    returning value(kind) type if_abap_prob_types=>distribution_kind.

  "! Returns whether the probability distribution is continuous
  "! @parameter continuous | Flag indicating if the distribution is continuous.
  methods is_continuous
    returning value(continuous) type abap_bool.

  "! Returns the mean of the probability distribution
  "! @parameter mean | The mean value of the distribution.
  "! @raising CX_ABAP_PROB_UNSUPPORTED | if distribution has no mean
  methods mean
    returning value(mean) type f
    raising   cx_abap_prob_unsupported.

  "! Returns a possible mode of the probability distribution
  "! @parameter mode | The mode of the distribution.
  "! @raising CX_ABAP_PROB_UNSUPPORTED | if distribution has no mode
  methods mode
    returning value(mode) type f
    raising   cx_abap_prob_unsupported.

  "! Returns the variance of the probability distribution
  "! @parameter variance | The variance of the distribution.
  "! @raising CX_ABAP_PROB_UNSUPPORTED | if distribution has no variance
  methods variance
    returning value(variance) type f
    raising   cx_abap_prob_unsupported.

  "! Returns the (CDF-based) median of the probability distribution. Here, the median
  "! is the smallest x in the support, such that P(X <= x) >= 0.5.
  "! @parameter median | The median value of the distribution.
  methods median
    returning value(median) type f.

  "! Returns the cumulative distribution function, i.e. the probability that the
  "! distribution assumes values <= arg.
  "! @parameter arg                      | The argument for which to calculate the cumulative distribution function.
  "! @parameter probability              | P( X <= arg )
  "! @raising cx_sy_arithmetic_overflow  | If an arithmetic overflow occurs.
  "! @raising cx_parameter_invalid_range | If the parameter is outside of the support.
  methods cdf
    importing arg                type f
    returning value(probability) type f
    raising   cx_sy_arithmetic_overflow
              cx_parameter_invalid_range.

  "! Returns the probability density function (if continuous) or the probability mass function
  "! (if not continuous)
  "! @parameter arg                      | The argument for which to calculate the probability density or mass function.
  "! @parameter value                    | The calculated density or mass value.
  "! @raising cx_sy_arithmetic_overflow  | If an arithmetic overflow occurs.
  "! @raising cx_parameter_invalid_range | If the parameter is outside of the support.
  methods pdf_or_pmf
    importing arg          type f
    returning value(value) type f
    raising   cx_sy_arithmetic_overflow
              cx_parameter_invalid_range.

  "! Returns the p-quantile of the the distribution,
  "! @parameter probability              | The probability for which to calculate the quantile. Should be
  "!                                       between 0 and 1.
  "! @parameter quantile                 | The calculated quantile value.
  "! @raising cx_parameter_invalid_range | If the parameter is out of range.
  "! @raising cx_sy_arithmetic_overflow  | If an arithmetic overflow occurs.
  methods quantile
    importing probability     type f
    returning value(quantile) type f
    raising   cx_parameter_invalid_range
              cx_sy_arithmetic_overflow.

  "! Returns the minimum value the distribution can assume.
  "! @parameter value | The minimum value in the distribution.
  methods min_value
    returning value(value) type f.

  "! Returns the maximum value the distribution can assume
  "! @parameter value | The maximum value in the distribution.
  methods max_value
    returning value(value) type f.

  "! Returns a random number distributed according to the distribution
  "! @parameter rng    | The random number generator to use.
  "!                     When rng is of type {@link CL_ABAP_RANDOM }, other algorithms are used
  "!                     which are significantly faster and generate different random numbers for some
  "!                     distributions.
  "! @parameter number | The next random number generated.
  methods next_random_number
    importing rng           type ref to if_abap_random
    returning value(number) type f.

  "! Returns an internal table of random number distributed according to the distribution
  "! @parameter count   | The number of random numbers to generate.
  "! @parameter rng     | The random number generator to use.
  "!                      When rng is of type {@link CL_ABAP_RANDOM }, other algorithms are used
  "!                      which are significantly faster and generate different random numbers for some
  "!                      distributions.
  "! @parameter numbers | A set of generated random numbers.
  methods next_random_numbers
    importing count          type i
              rng            type ref to if_abap_random
    returning value(numbers) type random_numbers.

endinterface.

entry.title: Devtoberfest 2025 Welcome!
entry.content:
We are thrilled to announce that Devtoberfest, an SAP TechEd event, returns this year running from September 29th - October 24th, 2025. It's a celebration for SAP developers and an excellent way to get ready for SAP TechEd. If you weren't around for Devtoberfest in 2020 -2024; here's a quick video overview of the event:

The Devtoberfest tracks have changed but no worries the new tracks are listed down below!

 
I’ll repeat the same overall description we’ve used the past few years as it does an excellent job of capturing the spirit of the event:

Devtoberfest is an attempt to capture the experience of the pre-conference events, like SAP InnoJam of years’ past. It’s an event which kicks off the SAP TechEd season. Devtoberfest takes some of the best aspects of the traditional hackathon type event, such as learning by building something, but opens the experience to the entire community and spreads across multiple weeks to better accommodate everyone’s busy schedules. It’s an event that is also designed for you to be able to participate asynchronously and on your own time schedule. As the idea formed, we’ve seen an opportunity here to really build something that is truly a festival for developers.

Devtoberfest – An open celebration of what makes us developers – Coding and Collaboration!
 
Getting Started with Devtoberfest
 
You are in the right place.  The home for the event will again be this SAP Community Group - where you find yourself right now. There is this dedicated SAP Community Group for Devtoberfest and all the individual events will be listed in the SAP Community Events calendar.  

This means no registration on a third-party event site or having to manually link to your SAP Community account. You register for Devtoberfest by reviewing the legal terms and conditions posted in this group and then just joining the Devtoberfest group. If you already joined in 2022, 2023 or 2024, then you are ready to participate again this year. 
 
Continuing with a similar overall approach as the last two years, this Devtoberfest will be ripe with educational and enablement sessions, opportunities to get hands-on with new and evolving developer tools, and a wonderful way to get you ready for the upcoming SAP TechEd event.
 
And if you prefer a video tutorial on signing up for Devtoberfest:

Educational Content
The backbone of Devtoberfest remains the educational content sessions. Devtoberfest is still an event designed for asynchronous consumption. While we will release content every weekday during Devtoberfest, it's all intended that you consume the content on your own schedule.
 
This year's tracks are the following:

🟢 Monday – ABAP

🟣 Tuesday – Tooling & Frontend

🔴Wednesday – Integration

🔵Thursday – Data & AI

🟠 Friday – CAP

🟡 All Week – Fun Activities

 
Fun Activities
This is a celebration so the Fun Friday activities will return, somewhat. This year we are changing things up a bit. Instead of having a Fun Friday, we have lots of fun activities sprinkled in throughout the week! There will be pro-active fun activities but also community fun activities like Petoberfest happening over the span of Devtoberfest.
We saw the greatest amount of participation last year in the activities that didn't require you to show up at a specific time, so we will continue to utilize those kinds of activities this year.
 
For all the information on the Fun Activities: coming soon!
 
The Contest
2022 saw the introduction of the grand prize of the Winner's Retreat to Newport Beach and Disneyland. It was great fun and hugely successful. The 2023 winners were joining us at the SAP TechEd road show (ASUG Tech Connect) in November 2024 which was an amazing experience.

The winners of 2024 are joining us this year (2025) in Berlin for SAP TechEd to learn, and to engage with SAP and the community! Congratulations to our 2024 winners!
 
When something works that well, why change it up; so again this year the grand prize for Devtoberfest will be a similar retreat to a future SAP TechEd event (in 2026). 
 
For all the information on the Content - coming soon!
For the Contest Official Rules - Devtoberfest 2025 Contest Official Rules - SAP Community
And we have a prize FAQ - Devtoberfest 2025 Grand Prize Trip FAQ - SAP Community
 
Questions, Comments, or Feedback
Questions about the event? Or the judging? Or you have a follow up question after participating in one of the educational enablement sessions? For any question or comment related to Devtoberfest we ask that you please use the dedicated Devtoberfest Discussions board available here.
 
Legal Stuff
It wouldn’t be any kind of event or contest without some legal content that I’m sure everyone will read in full detail. The legal terms and conditions for the 2025 event are coming soon.

entry.title: Re: Optimizing Data Action Script
entry.content:
Hi @nasser_itani 

The reason it takes 17 seconds to execute a single project is that the script contains five FOREACH statements. I believe the first "FOREACH [d/DIM_WBS_PROJECT]" statement is necessary, but for performance improvement, the remaining four FOREACH statements should be minimized.

The script contains many variables, and a corresponding FOREACH was executed to obtain the value of each variable. 

For performance improvement, Variables(INTEGER & FLOAT) and FOREACH statements should be minimized overall. However, the script optimization cannot be achieved solely based on the currently provided script. It appears that a comprehensive restructuring of the script is required.

Moonjun

entry.title: Re: MONITOR PURCHASE ORDER ITEM showing no data
entry.content:
Hello @JabinRubayat 

The issue where the Monitor Purchase Order Items (F2358) app is displaying no data. Below are the key checks and resolution steps.

Key Checks to me

Business Role Assignment

  • Ensure the user has the role SAP_BR_PURCHASER.
  • Verify catalog SAP_MM_BC_PO_MONITOR_PC is included.

Filter Settings

  • The app defaults to open & released POs only.
  • Draft, deleted, or completed POs will not appear.
  • Please broaden filters (supplier, purchasing org, company code) and search again.

Authorisation Restrictions

  • Business roles may restrict company codes, plants, or purchasing orgs.
  • Review value restrictions in Maintain Business Roles.

PO Status

  • Confirm in Manage Purchase Orders that the purchase orders are in Released status.
  • Newly created items may take time until the analytics refresh.

Possible Resolution Steps

  1.  Assign the SAP_BR_PURCHASER role to the user.
  2. Verify that the PO is in Released status.
  3. Run the application with all filters cleared.
  4. If there is still no data → review business role restrictions..

Check and refer to the below helpful SAP Documentation

  • SAP Help Portal: Monitor Purchase Order Items (F2358)
  • KBA 2790959 - Monitor Purchase Order Items: display of Fully received & invoiced POs
  • 3493638 - Number is not shown when using filter Order Date then save as tile in Fiori Monitor Purchase Order Item app

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Govern Your RISE Project using CALM/ACTIVATE for Integration Suite, Edge Integration Cell
entry.content:
When implementing SAP Integration Suite, Edge Integration Cell in a RISE with SAP project, you’ll quickly realize there’s more to it than just following the installation steps.
Multiple teams are involved — Basis, Integration, Security — and the process spans several weeks with dependencies, approvals, and testing.

That’s where SAP Cloud ALM (CALM) and the SAP Activate methodology come in.
Instead of treating the setup guide as a static document, you can turn it into a living, governed project plan in CALM — giving you visibility, accountability, and structure.

In this blog, I’ll walk you through how we built a CALM project plan directly from the SAP Help guide:
Setting up and Managing Edge Integration Cell
… and aligned it with SAP Activate phases to ensure nothing slipped through the cracks.

Why Governance Matters for Edge Integration Cell

The Edge Integration Cell extends your Integration Suite into on-premise or private cloud environments, ideal for hybrid integration scenarios.
But without governance:

  • Prerequisite checks get missed.
  • Network and security tasks are delayed.
  • The “who does what” question slows progress.

Using CALM + Activate solves these issues:

  • Phased approach (Prepare → Explore → Realize → Deploy → Run)
  • Task ownership and clear accountability
  • Built-in dependencies and milestone tracking

Building the CALM Project Plan from the SAP Help Guide

The SAP Help guide breaks the setup into logical sections — installation prerequisites, network configuration, deployment, operations.
We mirrored this structure in CALM:

  • Each section became a Work Package.
  • Each step in the guide became a Task, with an owner, due date, and link to the original help page.


The Edge Integration Cell setup as a governed CALM project — each work package represents a major setup step from SAP Help.


Detailed CALM task view — each task links directly to the relevant SAP Help step, ensuring consistent execution.

Example:

  • Work Package: Install Edge Integration Cell
    • Task: Prepare installation environment (linked to SAP Help section)
    • Task: Run installation script on target host
    • Task: Validate installation logs

Using SAP Activate in CALM

Once the work packages were in place, we assigned them to Activate phases:

  • Prepare: Check system prerequisites, plan network connectivity
  • Explore: Review architecture, finalize sizing & connectivity models
  • Realize: Perform installation, apply configurations
  • Deploy: Prepare go-live, complete handover documentation
  • Run: Set up monitoring, operational processes


Phase view in CALM shows the progression of the Edge Integration Cell setup across Activate stages.

Practical Tips for Making It Work

Through experience, these points made the biggest difference:

  1. Assign clear task owners — CALM Personas ensure accountability
  2. Use dependencies — Ensure network setup tasks finish before installation begins.
  3. Link every CALM task to the exact SAP Help step — removes ambiguity.
  4. Review progress at each Activate phase gate — prevents issues from snowballing.

Conclusion

By combining CALM project planning with the SAP Activate methodology, you can transform the Edge Integration Cell setup from a static instruction list into a clear, collaborative, and governable project.

Whether you’re in a RISE project or a hybrid integration scenario, this approach ensures:

  • Everyone knows their tasks.
  • Steps happen in the right order.
  • Stakeholders can track progress in real-time.

If you need support on your SAP Integration Suite, Edge Cell journey, feel free to reach out to us via: SAP Integration Modernization <integration.modernization@sap.com>

entry.title: Error "Missing Customizing in table TFK028G (CAMT053 PMNTRCDTESCT H)" in FPB7 (RKKKKA00)
entry.content:
Dear all,

the error: “Missing Customizing in table TFK028G (CAMT053 PMNTRCDTESCT H).“ occurs in SAP S/4HANA On Premise System X client Y (S4CORE 106), when carrying out the transaction FPB7 (report RFKKKA00) to transfer relevant data of an electronic bank account statement (EBS) to FS-CD (FI-CA), particularly for creating a Payment Lot or a Return Lot, which contains all EBS header and item information.

Previously, the EBS has been created by importing an appropriate camt.053 XML file using the transaction FF_5.

According to the error message, an “H” is expected that might reference to the field “FEBEP-EPVOZ: Debit/Credit Key for Line Items (for Bank Purposes)”. This field is populated correctly in table FEBEP with an “H” or “S” depending on the item and its Business Transaction Code.

But:

In the FS-CD (FI-CA) Customizing “Define Transactions for Electronic Bank Statement Transfer”, View V_TFK028G, only entries – especially regarding the field TFK028G-VOZPM – can be maintained, which exist in the related FI-BL Bank Accounting Customizing 🡪 Business Transactions 🡪 Payment Transactions 🡪 Electronic Bank Statement: “Make Global Settings for Electronic Bank Statement” 🡪 section “Create Transaction Type” CAMT053 🡪 “Assign External Transaction Types to Posting Rules”:

ACMTACOPINTR              -
ACMTMDOPINTR            -
PMNTICDTAUTT              -
PMNTICDTBOOK             -
PMNTICDTDMCT             -
PMNTICDTPRCT               -
PMNTICDTRRTN              +
PMNTRCDTESCT              -
PMNTRCDTVCOM           -

There is no “S” or “H” as an attribute of the External Transaction Type in view field V_T028G-VOZPM (respective table field T028G-VOZPM), but as listed an “-“ or “+”.

Many thanks in advance for your support to avoid this issue in advance, or to solve the problem that causes this error (e.g. by an installation-specific function module maybe, in FI-CA / FS-CD event 953).

Kind regards,
Jochem

entry.title: Bringing Back Badges to Reward Q&A Experts!
entry.content:
If you’ve been a long-time member of SAP Community, you’ve probably accumulated several badges over the years. Even newer members may have earned the basic one-time badges available on our current platform – such as the badge for taking our tutorial and the various badges awarded for a first-time action (e.g., replying, leaving a kudo). Members haven’t, however, been able to receive ongoing recognition for repeated activity.

That will change starting tomorrow (Tuesday, August 19).

With our previous gamification system, we rewarded badges for posting quality content, providing helpful answers, and more – giving members the opportunity to earn multiple awards for frequent participation. (As an example, take a look at my list of badges – which pales compared to the accomplishments of veterans who have been around since the earliest days of our online community!) As of August 19, we’re bringing this recognition back, starting with progression badges based on the number of answers accepted as solutions.

If you like answering questions (and you’re gifted at helping other members find solutions to their problems), then you’ve probably already received the first badge in this new series – by giving an answer that was accepted as a solution. Now you can earn an additional four badges, depending on the number of solutions you provided in Q&A.

We’ll be rewarding people retroactively, so depending on your Q&A activity and length of community membership (going back to previous community platforms), you may get one or more badges tomorrow.

Not sure of your numbers? You can find them in your community content area. After logging in, click on the person icon in the upper right of any community page, then select “My content.”

You’ll see your total number of answers in the Private Stats section at the bottom of your “My content” area.

But remember: an answer is not a solution. An answer becomes a solution when someone accepts it as the correct answer to a question. You’ll find your total number of solutions in the gray box at the top of your “My content” page.

So in this example, this member should expect to get all four of the new solutions badges. With 93 solutions, he has achieved the necessary criteria for the second badge (2 solutions), third badge (5 solutions), fourth badge (25 solutions), and the fifth and final badge in this progression series (50 solutions). (I sure hope he’s reading this, so he won’t wonder what’s going on when he sees four badge notifications tomorrow.)

With this new badge set, SAP Community is once again acknowledging the awesome members who regularly contribute quality content. And we’re not stopping here! In the near future, we plan to introduce other progression sets. We don’t want to give away too much information just yet – we thought it would be fun to keep things a surprise – but we do encourage you to get more active, as you may find yourself receiving bigger badge payoffs very soon.

Make sure to monitor the What’s New section for announcements about the new progression badge sets as they become available. In the meantime, if you frequently participate in the community, keep up the good work. Or if you’re more of a lurker, consider jumping in and building up the numbers necessary for badges. Depending on what you do (and what you’ve done), you may find yourself the recipient of several shiny new badges as we extend the ways in which we show appreciation for those who make our community a better place!

OK, one hint: We aren’t just going to reward the members active in Q&A, so if answering questions isn’t your thing, you can still gain badges for other activities. Experiment with meaningful contributions, show your support for other members, and see what happens!

entry.title: Re: Clear Salary outside HireDate and TerminationDate ranges, and calculate per day salary
entry.content:
So I split the code into two and it works now

CONFIG.HIERARCHY.INCLUDE_MEMBERS_NOT_IN_HIERARCHY = [d/Account], [d/CostCenter], [d/Emp_Status], [d/Employee], [d/LegalEntity], [d/Location]
CONFIG.GENERATE_UNBOOKED_DATA = ON

MEMBERSET [d/Measures] = "Amount_LC"
MEMBERSET [d/Account] = "ACC_017"
MEMBERSET [d/DataSource] = "DS_PAYROLL"
MEMBERSET [d/Employee] = (BASEMEMBER([d/Employee].[h/EmpStatus], "ACTIVE", "TERMINATED", "TO_BE_HIRED", "INACTIVE"))

// Hire Date Proration
IF DATEDIFF([d/HireDate], [d/Date], "MONTH") < 0 THEN
    DATA([d/Account] = "ACC_017", [d/Measures] = "Amount_LC", [d/DataSource] = "DS_PAYROLL") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC") * 0
ELSE
    IF DATEDIFF([d/HireDate], [d/Date], "DAY") < 0 THEN
        DATA([d/Account] = "ACC_017", [d/Measures] = "Amount_LC", [d/DataSource] = "DS_PAYROLL") =
            (1 - ABS(DATEDIFF([d/HireDate], [d/Date], "DAY")) / DAYSINMONTH([d/Date])) * RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC")
    ELSE
        // Full month if hired before this month
        DATA([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC")
    ENDIF
ENDIF

Here is the code for reference, Thanks @William_Yu1 and @Chuma for trying to help me.

entry.title: Calling SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud APIs from SAP Integration Suite with OAuth 2.0
entry.content:
Hi all,

I can connect from SAP Integration Suite (Cloud Integration) to S/4HANA Public Cloud APIs using Basic Authentication, but I’d like to switch to OAuth 2.0 for better security.

When I try to set up a communication system/arrangement, the only inbound OAuth option I see is OAuth 2.0 (Public Client, PKCE). I don’t see OAuth 2.0 Identity Provider (which I would normally expect for certificate-based SAML Bearer Assertion).

So far:

  • Basic Auth works fine.

  • I created a key pair in CPI keystore and uploaded the cert to S/4, but inbound OAuth user creation still only shows PKCE.

  • Customers are asking for a more secure approach than Basic Auth.

My questions:

  1. Is OAuth2 SAML Bearer Assertion officially supported for inbound calls to S/4HANA Public Cloud from Integration Suite?

  2. If so, how do I enable the Identity Provider option in inbound communication users? Is it tenant-specific?

  3. If not, what is the best practice today for securing these integrations beyond Basic Auth?

Thanks in advance for clarifications or official references.

entry.title: Re: What's the best way to see material stock and history...
entry.content:
Hi Marcelo

Have you considered exploring the built-in Analytics available in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition?

For example, the Inventory Analysis Overview (https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/index.html#/detail/Apps('F3366')/S35)

Or Analyze Stock in Range

The section in the Help covering Inventory Analytics and Control covers a number of other available apps and analytics like Goods Movement Analysis, Dead Stock, Inventory Turnover, etc. 

To directly answer your question, you can utilize the View Browser to search on the table name, but you may find a consumption table that is not released, or the table is represented by several views.

There likely will not be a 1:1 view for each table

If you can let us know more about your business requirement, we might be able to better answer your question or point you in the right direction.

Thank you

Jerry

entry.title: Re: CDS Hierarchy Directory: How to use NOTASSIGNEDNODE Annotation to suppress or to filter the Not
entry.content:
Hi 

you can try  @AnalyticsDetails.query.hierarchySettings.childNodePosition: #ABOVE to specify child node  position to upwards.

 

and Following is the table defination for zoq_connid_hd -

@EndUserText.label : 'Hierarchy directory for ConnectionID (SFLIGHT)'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #ALLOWED
define table zoq_connid_hd {

  key hieid    : zoq_conhieid not null;
  hiertxt      : rstxtlg;
  last_changed : rstimestmp;

}

I hope it helps.
